question: Question_01_(g)
statement:
\emph{\textbf{Short-Answer Questions.} Put your answer in the box
provided but show your work also. Each question is worth 3 marks, but
not all questions are of equal difficulty. Full marks will be given for
correct answers placed in the box, but at most 1 mark will be given for
incorrect answers. Unless otherwise stated, it is not necessary to
simplify your answers in this question.}

A vertical cylindrical tank with radius \emph{3m} is being filled with
water at a rate of \emph{5m\textsuperscript{3}/min}. How fast is the
height of the water increasing?
sols:
The two variables that are changing in this problem are the volume of
water and the height of the water. These two variables are related in
the formula for volume of a cylinder:

\begin{align*}V = \pi r^2 h\end{align*} For this problem, we know that the radius of the
cylinder is 3, so we can put that into our formula to get:

\begin{align*}V = 9\pi  h\end{align*} Since the question is asking about rates of change, we
will differentiate the above formula with respect to \emph{t}.

\begin{align*}\frac{dV}{dt} = 9\pi\frac{dh}{dt}\end{align*} In this new formula, \emph{dh/dt}
stands for the rate at which the height of the water is changing, which
is what we're solving for. We also know that \emph{dV/dt} stands for the
rate at which the volume of water is changing, which is \emph{5
m\textsuperscript{3}/min}. So substituting in \emph{dV/dt = 5} we have:

\begin{align*}5 = 9\pi\frac{dh}{dt}\end{align*} And solving for \emph{dh/dt} we get:

\begin{align*}\frac{dh}{dt} = \frac{5}{9\pi} m/min\end{align*}
